speaker: AARON MONTE
line: Eugene? Eugene, it's Dr. Monte. Eugene, are you asleep?

speaker: EUGENE TOOMS
line: No.

speaker: AARON MONTE
line: I was on my way out and wanted to stop by and see how you were feeling.

speaker: EUGENE TOOMS
line: Fine.

speaker: AARON MONTE
line: Good. You nervous about tomorrow? Don't be. I know you think they won't let you out so I snuck a peek at the reports of the doctors that will testify at your review tomorrow and they concur with my opinion that you're ready to be released from here...

speaker: EUGENE TOOMS
line: Hmmm...

speaker: AARON MONTE
line: And rejoin the community. So... Why don't we get some sleep and relax and I'll see you tomorrow at the review, okay? Let's just keep our fingers crossed.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Agent Scully, we have reviewed your reports and frankly we are quite displeased. Irregular procedure, untenable evidence, anonymous witnesses, inconclusive findings aggravated by vague opinion.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But sir, the very nature of the X-Files cases often precludes orthodox investigation.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Are you suggesting that the bureau adopt separate standards for you and Agent Mulder?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, sir.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Are you suggesting that Agent Mulder obstructs you from proper procedure?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, sir. If anything, I'm suggesting that these cases be reviewed with... an open mind.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Maybe your mind has become too open.

speaker: SCULLY
line: On X-Files cases investigated by Agent Mulder and myself to date, we have a conviction or case solution of seventy-five percent. That's well above the current bureau standard.

speaker: SKINNER
line: And that is your only saving grace.

speaker: SCULLY
line: May I ask, sir, what more you require?

speaker: SKINNER
line: What I require is increased frequency of reports. Conventional investigation. In short, Agent Scully, it is your responsibility to see that these cases are by-the-book.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I understand, however... conventional investigation of these cases may decrease the rate of success.

speaker: JUDGE KANN
line: By order of the state of Maryland, the court shall review the psychological status of Eugene Victor Tooms. We'll begin with the court-appointed expert witnesses. The court calls Dr. Pamela Karetzky.

speaker: DR. KARETZKY
line: I performed several diagnostic procedures on Mr. Tooms in order to determine any organic physiological dysfunction - an electroencephalogram, chromosomal analysis, a computerized axial tomograph. All of these were negative.

speaker: DR. COLLINS
line: "Mr. Tooms had recently lost his job," Parenthesis: "Baltimore Animal Regulation" slash "Dog Catcher," close parenthesis. "Aggravated by a false arrest incident with the FBI, his assault on Agent Scully was," quote, "frustration directed at the wrong person," end quote.

speaker: AARON MONTE
line: I'm reading from a recent interview I did with Mr. Tooms and animals." So you see, what is occuring here is that Mr. Tooms is learning to articulate his feelings and invest his emotional energy towards creative and constructive activity......strategem neurotic build-up in himself. It is my opinion that Mr. Tooms has had a very excellent response to the months of treatment and therapy and I would see no reason why he would be considered of any danger to himself or any member of society.

speaker: WOMAN
line: Do you swear that the testimony you are about to deliver is the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth?

speaker: MULDER
line: I do.

speaker: PROSECUTION COUNSEL MYERS
line: Mr. Mulder, as an expert witness for the state of Maryland, can you list your qualifications?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm a special agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, I worked for three years at the F.B.I.'s behavioral science unit profiling serial killers.

speaker: DEFENSE COUNSEL NELSON
line: Your honor, I know where he's going this. May I remind the court that Mr. Tooms was placed in psychiatric care solely for the previous assault on Agent Scully. He has never been charged, nor has any evidence linked him to another crime.

speaker: JUDGE KANN
line: You may proceed... with caution.

speaker: PROSECUTION COUNSEL MYERS
line: Agent Mulder, I understand that you've drawn upon your experience and developed a profile on Mr. Tooms.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes, I have.

speaker: PROSECUTION COUNSEL MYERS
line: Please.

speaker: MULDER
line: These murders span nearly a century. Nineteen homicides, five occuring every thirty years since 1903, all in the Baltimore area. In each case, the liver was extracted and presumably eaten. A trophy was taken, many of which were found in the living quarters of Eugene Tooms at 66 Exeter Street. Records show that a Eugene Tooms has resided at that same address since 1903, the same year a man was murdered in that building. Besides the liver extraction, the most notable element connecting these cases is the undetermined point of entry. Many of the victims were found with their windows and doors locked from the inside. These elongated fingerprints found at seven of the nineteen crime sites match Eugene Victor Tooms.

speaker: JUDGE KANN
line: Agent Mulder! Look at his fingers. Look at him! 100 years old?

speaker: MULDER
line: I contend that perhaps through genetic mutation, Eugene Tooms is capable of contorting and elongating his body in order to gain access to victims so that he may extract the livers which provide him with sustenance for the hibernation period of 30 years. He needs one more liver to complete this cycle.

speaker: DEFENSE COUNSEL NELSON
line: Your honor...

speaker: MULDER
line: A preliminary examination done at the time of Tooms' arrest revealed abnormalities in his striated muscles and axial bones. His attorney blocked further study...

speaker: PROSECTION COUNSEL MYERS
line: Thank you, Agent Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: I must ask that you place the safety of...

speaker: JUDGE KANN
line: Counsel?

speaker: MULDER
line: ...the people first and foremost...

speaker: DEFENSE COUNSEL NELSON
line: No further questions, your honor.

speaker: MULDER
line: This is a rare and unusual human creature...

speaker: JUDGE KANN
line: Agent Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: ...who should not be released, but should be retained for further study.

speaker: JUDGE KANN
line: You may step down!

speaker: MULDER
line: If you release Eugene Tooms, he will kill again. It's in his genetic make-up. You think they would have taken me more seriously if I wore the grey suit?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, your testimony, you sounded so...

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't care how it sounded as long as it was the truth. And where were you? Your testimony was important.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I was called into a meeting by Assistant Director Skinner.

speaker: MULDER
line: What did he want?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Just wanted to reel me in.

speaker: PROSECUTION COUNSEL MYERS
line: They're ready.

speaker: JUDGE KANN
line: It is the opinion of this court that Eugene Victor Tooms shall on this daybe released from Druid Hill Sanitarium. The court also attaches these conditions. One, that Mr. Tooms remain in counseling under the care of Dr. Aaron Monte; that he retain his job at the Baltimore Regulations Animal Shelter; and last, that he take residence in the house of Mr. and Mrs. Arlan Green...... trained in a program to assist patients released from Druid Hill in their transition to society. Mr. Tooms? Do you understand and accept these conditions?

speaker: EUGENE TOOMS
line: Yes, your honor.

speaker: JUDGE KANN
line: Very well. You're free to go.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not taking my eyes off him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, wait...

speaker: MULDER
line: He needs to kill, he'll do it the first chance he can but he won't kill the old couple. He won't be that obvious. Tooms didn't remain a secret for a hundred years by not being careful. Think of him as an animal. He'll only kill out of necessity or self-defense. If he makes an attempt, I'll be there to stop him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Okay, well then I'll keep surveillance with you.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, I'll watch him. If he can't be tied to the most recent evidence, you'll have to go back to the earlier murders to prove it was him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That was thirty or sixty years ago.

speaker: MULDER
line: There's no statute of limitation on murder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, that's going to entail unorthodox methods of investigation.

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, Scully, if you're resistant because you don't believe, I'll respect that. But if you're resistant because of some bureaucratic pressure, they've not only reeled you in. They've already skinned you.

speaker: ARLAN GREEN
line: I hope you'll be comfortable, Eugene. The room in the back is small, but I'm sure you'll be able to squeeze in.

speaker: EUGENE TOOMS
line: I'm sure.

speaker: MULDER
line: Excuse me. Could you help me find my dog? He's a Norweigan Elkhound. His name is Heinrich. I use him to hunt moose.

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: If Tooms gets away now then the next time he takes a life, you'll be nearly my age.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Detective Briggs, you've helped us so much before. Now we have to prove that Tooms was involved in the killings you investigated thirty years ago. You've lived with this case half your life. There must be something. Maybe a connection between the victims. Now, I know that we've seen all the evidence, but is there anything, anything at all amongst the evidence that doesn't fit?

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: There was something that never did sit quite right with me. All of the victims that I investigated in '63 were found at the crime scene, liver extracted. All five.

speaker: SCULLY
line: As were the four most recent murders.

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: When I was a sherrif during the Powhatan Mill killings of 1933, only four of the victims were found at the crime scene. However, there was a fifth person who was missing and never found. But this, this was discovered at the Ruxton Chemical Plant when it was under construction. But it doesn't belong to the other victims.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That doesn't prove that it belongs to a person murdered by Tooms.

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: I'm positive that Tooms hid this one victim because there was something about the body that could prove he was the killer.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And what makes you positive?

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: A hunch. A good old-fashioned hunch. You've got to trust your instincts.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And what does your instincts say about where Tooms buried the body?

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: In the cement where they poured the foundation of the chemical plant.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ground-penetrating radar. It bounces signals off of objects or cavities.

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: Tells you where the body is.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it signals if something inordinate is present. An experienced operator attempts to differentiate if the signal is a body or is stone or a hole in the ground.

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: Differentiate?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mm-hmmm.

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: You mean he guesses?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it's an educated guess.

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: Mm-hmmm.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How are we doing?

speaker: OPERATOR
line: Well, it's really hard to tell. There are some possibilities... very few places...

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: It's here. Here!

speaker: MAN
line: What is it?

speaker: FRANK BRIGGS
line: It's here. It's right here!

speaker: AIR HOSE MAN
line: Agent Scully? Look at this.

speaker: CHRISTINE RANFORD
line: Robotoddler's finally asleep. I'm going to go to bed.

speaker: FRANK RANFORD
line: Okay.

speaker: CHRISTINE RANFORD
line: I'm coming, honey. Mommy's right here. Shh, shh. Screw it. Would you go down and get that?

speaker: MULDER
line: F.B.I. I suspect an intruder in your house.

speaker: FRANK RANFORD
line: What? Someone opened my window.

speaker: DR. PLITH
line: I suspect the year of death to be in the mid-1930’s. The anterior surface of the right femur was green indicating a long-term exposure to copper. So we concentrated on the area and we found several pennies. 1933, ’31, 1933...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Can you determine the cause of death? My instinct says that burial in cement is murder.

speaker: DR. PLITH
line: Ah, no. At the moment, I have found no definite proof of murder. There are gnawing marks near the ribs, however, I suspect that’s the result of rodent activity prior to the body being set in cement. We’ll need to see much more of the remains to determine cause of death. As you know, it’s a slow but necessary process. Uh, I did try a little something. It’s a little premature if we’re going to go by-the-book.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, we’ll keep it off the record.

speaker: DR. PLITH
line: Good, thank you. The old man, Briggs, he gave me a photograph of the missing person in 1933 suspected of being a murder victim. I ran a computer-assisted photographic superimposition on what we have of the skull. Now, this is not official... but that skeleton was that person.

speaker: MULDER
line: It’s not enough. It doesn’t tie it to Tooms.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it’s a start. Mulder, it’s getting a bit ripe in here, don’t you think?

speaker: MULDER
line: Pine-scented.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ooh!

speaker: MULDER
line: Better? Tooms hasn’t come out of the house all day. I sat through a Phillies game, an Orioles game, and four hours of Ba-Ba-Booey. When it got dark, I took a walk around the block. Do you have that sandwich that I asked you to bring?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It’s liverwurst.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ha-ha.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, you know that proper surveillance requires two pairs of agents, one pair relieving the other after twelve hours.

speaker: MULDER
line: Article 30, paragraph 8.7?

speaker: SCULLY
line: This isn’t about doing it by the book. This is about you not having slept for three days. Mulder, you’re going to get sloppy and you’re going to get hurt. It’s inevitable at this point.

speaker: MULDER
line: A request for other agents to stake-out Tooms would be denied. Then we have no grounds.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, then I’ll stay here. You go home.

speaker: MULDER
line: They’re out to put an end to the X-Files, Scully. I don’t know why, but any excuse will do. Now, I don’t really care about my record, but you’d be in trouble just for sitting in this car and I’d hate to see you to carry an official reprimand in your file because of me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Fox...

speaker: MULDER
line: And I... I even made my parents call me Mulder. So... Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I wouldn’t put myself on the line for anybody but you.

speaker: MULDER
line: If there’s an ice tea in that bag, could be love.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Must be fate, Mulder. Root beer. You’re delirious. Go home and get some sleep.

speaker: MULDER
line: Here. Take my sandwich, I only had one bite. You’re gonna want it later, believe me. And you’ll call me if anything happens, immediately. I’ll be here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wouldn’t miss it for the world.

speaker: NURSE ON TV
line: It has worked, hasn’t it? You’ll be all right now. I know it worked! No! No! Nooo!!!!

speaker: DETECTIVE TALBOT
line: Yeah, they found him out cold in the street.

speaker: DR. RICHMOND
line: He’s been beaten up pretty badly. Contusions, multiple lacerations. Shoulder’s been pulled right out of joint. Let’s get him prepped for some blood work and X-rays.

speaker: MALE NURSE
line: Yes, doctor.

speaker: DR. RICHMOND
line: He’s been kicked in the jaw and it may be fractured. Look, there’s a partial shoeprint.

speaker: DETECTIVE TALBOT
line: I want to get a photo of that, we might be able to find the shoe that matches it later.

speaker: DR. RICHMOND
line: Do you know who did this to you? We’ll be right back, Mr. Tooms. Says it’s an F.B.I. agent named Mulder.

speaker: DETECTIVE TALBOT
line: So would you say he’s delusional or just schizophrenic?

speaker: DR. RICHMOND
line: Well, it’s just a cursory exam, but there’s nothing to indicate that.

speaker: DETECTIVE TALBOT
line: Agent Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. What’s going on? What’s this about?

speaker: DETECTIVE TALBOT
line: Agent Mulder, get your things. You’re in some trouble.

speaker: SKINNER
line: These are serious allegations, Agent Mulder, the evidence is incriminating.

speaker: MULDER
line: A good forensic scientist would know that there is not only a shoe print but also an impact point from inside the shoe. An indepth analysis of Tooms’ injury would show that my foot was not inside the shoe at the time of impact.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Mulder, are you suggesting that Tooms is framing you?

speaker: MULDER
line: Of course.

speaker: SKINNER
line: If indeed you were engaged in an unauthorized round-the-clock surviellance of Tooms, how could he possibly gain access to your shoe without you seeing him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sir? I was engaged in the unauthorized surveillance as well and Agent Mulder was orienting me on the situation at the time Tooms was admitted into the hospital. Agent Mulder could not have done it because he was with me.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Agent Scully, you wouldn’t be lying in me, would you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sir, I would expect you to place the same trust in me as I do in you.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Agent Scully, may I have a word with Agent Mulder, please? Fox, you are one of the finest, most unique agents in the nearly sixty-year history of this institution. I mean, we were talking about you when you were in the academy. Now, most of us, including the director, feel that your talents are wasted on the X-Files but we respect that you’re deeply invested in those areas. But if these areas are creating such stress as to not only cause you to act inappropriately but those agents close to you as well then may I advise you to step away... for a while. Clear your head, take an extended vacation.

speaker: MULDER
line: That’s a good idea. Thanks for your concern.

speaker: SKINNER
line: You’re forbidden to go near Eugene Tooms. Mulder... This was close. Any closer and a thousand friends at the capitol won’t be able to help you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: These are Eugene Tooms’ dental x-rays obtained from the Druid Hill Sanitarium. Your sandwich the other night gave me an idea. Dr. Plith had mentioned that he found gnawing on the rib cage near the location of the liver. Further excavation revealed more pronounced bite marks, human teeth marks.

speaker: MULDER
line: Tooms will never voluntarily submit to a dental cast.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This software can create an exact three-dimensional model of Tooms’ mouth from the dental radiograph.

speaker: DR. PLITH
line: We’ve also mapped out the bite marks on the skeleton’s rib... there. They match.

speaker: ARLAN GREEN
line: Eugene, Doctor Monte.

speaker: AARON MONTE
line: Hi, Eugene. I just wanted to stop by and see how everything was going.

speaker: ARLAN GREEN
line: Susan and I are going out for the evening. See you later.

speaker: AARON MONTE
line: Thanks. Great place. Wonderful place. How are you feeling? Why the newspaper strips, Eugene? Are you making some paper-mache?

speaker: EUGENE TOOMS
line: Yes.

speaker: AARON MONTE
line: That’s terrific. Wonderful, I had no idea you were interested in art.

speaker: EUGENE TOOMS
line: I like art.

speaker: AARON MONTE
line: I do too and I’m very proud of you. You know, art can provide a window to your thoughts and your feelings...what are you doing, Eugene? Eugene? Are you alright?

speaker: MULDER
line: That makes five. He’s building his nest. Thirty year hibernation.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where would he go?

speaker: MULDER
line: Where he’s gone for the last ninty years, 66 Exeter Street.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, I already checked on that. They tore down that apartment building he lived in.

speaker: MULDER
line: What’s there now?

speaker: MULDER
line: Thanks. He’s got to be here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: If he is drawn to this location for some reason, maybe this nest is in the approximate location of his previous nest. This is the area. There’s a storage facility on the second floor. What? There’s only room for one.

speaker: MULDER
line: You can get the next mutant.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder? Mulder! Mulder! Mulder, here! Quick, grab my hand! Come on! Just a little...

speaker: SKINNER
line: You read this report? Do you believe them?

speaker: CSM
line: Of course I do.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Okay, let’s go.

speaker: MULDER
line: It’s amazing how things change, isn’t it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The caterpillar?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, a change for us. It’s coming.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How do you know?

speaker: MULDER
line: A hunch.
